senses.de: A difference between two things that should be the same
senses.ex: There was a large discrepancy between the test results, causing confusion among the researchers.

Tips.title: Expectation Mismatch
Tips.description: Used when two similar items don't match as expected.
Tips.example: We found a discrepancy between the listed price and the checkout price.

Tips.title: Conflict Evidence
Tips.description: Indicates conflicting information found when comparing items.
Tips.example: Her alibi shows a discrepancy with the security footage.

Tips.title: Descriptive Nuance
Tips.example: He observed a slight discrepancy in the twins' behavior.

senses.de: A failure to match or correspond
senses.ex: The court noted a discrepancy between the witness's testimony and the evidence presented.

Tips.title: Legal Inconsistency
Tips.description: Points out contradictions in legal documents or proceedings.
Tips.example: The lawyer exploited the discrepancy in the suspect's statements.

Tips.title: Evidence Analysis
Tips.description: Used to scrutinize inconsistencies in data or testimonies.
Tips.example: Discrepancies in the reports called for further investigation.

senses.de: An error in calculation or measurement
senses.ex: A discrepancy in the calculations led to inaccurate conclusions.

Tips.title: Accuracy Importance
Tips.description: Emphasizes the need for precise data in technical fields.
Tips.example: The engineer noted a discrepancy in the blueprint measurements.

Tips.title: Critical Errors
Tips.description: Refers to mistakes with impactful consequences.
Tips.example: A slight discrepancy in the dosage can have severe effects.

Tips.title: Precision Needed
Tips.description: Highlights situations where exactness is crucial.
Tips.example: Any discrepancy in the code caused the program to crash.

Consistency.wordDefinition:
Consistency refers to the quality of being consistent or constant; it means that something always behaves or operates in the same way.

Discrepancy refers to a difference or inconsistency between two or more things. It means that there is a disagreement or variation between two or more items, datasets or individuals.

Consistency is about something staying the same, while discrepancy is about identifying differences. Consistency is applicable when you want something to remain uniform, such as in a scientific experiment, where you want to keep all conditions the same to obtain accurate results.

Discrepancy is applicable when you need to identify errors, gaps or inconsistencies in data, such as in accounting, where the balance sheet must match up with the cash flow statement.

Contradiction.wordDefinition:
A contradiction is when two statements or ideas cannot both be true at the same time. For example, saying "I am always honest" and then lying would be a contradiction.

A contradiction means two things can't both be true, while a discrepancy means there's a difference between two things, but they may each still be true in their own way.

Difference.wordDefinition:
Difference refers to the distinction or variation between two or more things. For instance, a company can make a difference in the community by donating funds to a charity.

Difference describes variations between two or more things, whereas discrepancy is used to indicate an inconsistency or a mismatch between data or expectation.

Disagree.wordDefinition:
Disagree means to have a different opinion or belief from someone else.

Example: John and Mary disagree on which movie to watch.

Disagree is used when people don't agree with each other, while discrepancy is used when things don't match up or are inconsistent with each other.

Disparity.wordDefinition:
Disparity refers to a difference or inequality between two or more things, such as ideas, values, or conditions.

For example, if one group of people has access to better healthcare than another group, there is a disparity in their access to healthcare.

Discrepancy refers to a difference in specific details, while disparity refers to a broader difference in overall conditions.

Divergence.wordDefinition:
Divergence means a separation or difference in opinions, beliefs, or paths taken.

It is used when two things that were once similar or connected begin to move apart or differ. For example, two friends who used to have similar interests may experience a divergence in their interests as they grow older and develop different hobbies.

Discrepancy describes a difference or inconsistency in information, while divergence describes a separation or difference in opinions, beliefs, or paths taken.

Imbalance.wordDefinition:
Imbalance refers to an uneven or unequal distribution of something, such as resources or power.

It is often used in situations where there is an unfairness or lack of equilibrium, such as an imbalance in the distribution of wealth or an imbalance of power between two groups.

Discrepancy is used when there is a difference between two things that are expected to be the same, while imbalance is used when there is a lack of equality or fairness in the distribution of something.

Variance.wordDefinition:
Variance means a difference between an expected outcome and an actual outcome.

It is used when something deviates from what was predicted or planned. For example, if a business predicted it would earn $10,000 in a month but only earned $8,000, we would say there is a variance between the expected and actual earnings.

Discrepancy refers to a difference between two things that should be the same, while variance describes a difference between an expected outcome and an actual outcome.

quotes.Text: I believe that most people would like to cooperate in reducing waste, but to encourage them, the national policy should be clear, well advertised, and consistent. Even within Greater London, there is a huge discrepancy between council policies. I believe a national waste management initiative should be designed and implemented by government.
quotes.Title: English Actor
quotes.Name: Jeremy Irons

quotes.Text: One of the things I learned early on was the system of believing: you have to believe in what you say. The camera is the arbiter of truth; it's the all-seeing eye that can pick out discrepancies. You can't lie to the camera. You must believe in what you're saying, or the audience won't believe you.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Wes Studi

quotes.Text: If we divine a discrepancy between a man's words and his character, the whole impression of him becomes broken and painful; he revolts the imagination by his lack of unity, and even the good in him is hardly accepted.
quotes.Title: American Sociologist
quotes.Name: Charles Horton Cooley

quotes.Text: Any architectural project we do takes at least four or five years, so increasingly there is a discrepancy between the acceleration of culture and the continuing slowness of architecture.
quotes.Title: Dutch Architect
quotes.Name: Rem Koolhaas

quotes.Text: Sometimes, indeed, there is such a discrepancy between the genius and his human qualities that one has to ask oneself whether a little less talent might not have been better.
quotes.Title: Swiss Psychologist
quotes.Name: Carl Jung

quotes.Text: I do love shoes that make my legs longer. I have the upper body of someone who's 5ft 8in, so high heels help me even out the discrepancy.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Amy Adams

quotes.Text: An epic is not made by piecing together a set of heroic lays, adjusting their discrepancies and making them into a continuous narrative.
quotes.Title: British Poet
quotes.Name: Lascelles Abercrombie

quotes.Text: You have to look at the discrepancy between what you hoped and imagined and the reality of yourself and all your shortcomings.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Richard Grant

quotes.Text: No, I think that we've got a basic discrepancy here between the rule of law versus the rule of man.
quotes.Title: American Judge
quotes.Name: Roy Moore
